bestBHT.bht: Jesus wept, allowing nature to manifest itself and teaching us moderation in our tears. This sublime spectacle reveals the Son of God's perfect oneness with us in our humanity. His emotion underlies the stern law of the Kingdom, The wages of sin is death. In this touching and profound act, Jesus shows us His profoundly human side, reminding us that even the Son of God shed tears in deep grief. No expression carries more meaning than this, emphasizing the significance of His tears.

Henry Alford: He wept, as allowing nature to manifest herself:.... there again he rebukes the affections." - Euthymius.
Only he assigns a didactic purpose, to teach us moderation in our tears." - Euthymius.
I should rather believe the self-restraint to have been exercised as a preparation for what followed." - Euthymius.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Is it for nothing that the Evangelist, some sixty years after it occurred, holds up to all ages with such touching brevity the sublime spectacle of the Son of God in tears?
What a seal of His perfect oneness with us in the most redeeming feature of our stricken humanity!
Who can doubt that in His ear every feature of the scene proclaimed that stern law of the Kingdom, 'The wages of sin is death,' and that this element in His visible emotion underlay all the rest?
Albert Barnes: Jesus wept - It has been remarked that this is the shortest verse in the Bible; but it is exceedingly important and tender.
It shows the Lord Jesus as a friend, a tender friend, and evinces his character as a man.
Marvin Vincent: The very Gospel in which the deity of Jesus is most clearly asserted, is also that which makes us best acquainted with the profoundly human side of His life" (Godet).

The gods while they dispense afflictions upon earth, which are neither sweetened by love, nor elevated by a distinct disciplinary purpose, take care to keep themselves beyond all touch of grief or care" (Gladstone).
Nature confesses that she gives the tenderest of hearts to the human race by giving them tears: this is the best part of our sensations" (Juvenal, "Satire" 14 131 - 133).
Archibald T. Robertson: Often all that we can do is to shed tears in grief too deep for words.
This is the shortest verse in the Bible, but no verse carries more meaning in it.
John Gill: This shows him to be truly and really man, subject to like passions, only without sin.

He was meditating upon the state of his friend Lazarus, the distress his two sisters were in, and the greater damnation that would befall the Jews then present, who, notwithstanding the miracle, would not believe in him.
John Wesley: Jesus wept — Out of sympathy with those who were in tears all around him.
Jesus wept — ...from a deep sense of the misery sin had brought upon human nature.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus wept, allowing nature to manifest itself and teaching us moderation in our tears in order to prepare for what followed. In this touching and sublime spectacle, the Son of God wept, sealing His perfect oneness with us in the most redeeming feature of our stricken humanity. His visible emotion underlies the stern law of the Kingdom, The wages of sin is death. Jesus, in His deity, shows us His profoundly human side. This shortest verse in the Bible is a profound reminder that even the Son of God wept, and often all we can do is shed tears in grief too deep for words. Truly, no verse carries more meaning in it than this one.

His emotion underlies the stern law of the Kingdom, The wages of sin is death. In this shortest passage, we see the profoundly human side of Jesus, reminding us that even the Son of God shed tears in deep grief. No passage carries more meaning than this, emphasizing the significance of his tears.
